content.description: Somebody left a stick clip (MacGyver'd with tape and plant stems). I tried without it, backed off, and then used it. It was a bit awkward, insecure, and friable (YMMV). I know these routes will clean up and enjoyed it after the opening move. See what you think.
content.protection: 8 bolts plus something for the chains.
content.location: This is about 100 feet passed the obvious roof of the Rabbit Hole, assuming you came across the higher path from Catslab. All 3 routes are above the old RR bridge abutments and this is the leftmost one. You may see the anchors first (left of the apex of the large roof), and follow the line down to the voluptuous (rounded) start. Rappel the route.

content.description:
This is not my route, but just past the Rabbit Hole are 3 routes Kevin Capps lists as The Fish Bowl in his new book. It needs a serious power-washing but is climbable. These may get better if more folks climbed them.

It starts on some rounded features and goes to a ramp to a headwall, moving left and up through a cleft. Then walk hard left to anchors over an obvious shelf. It is a fair way over to those anchors, but it's easy enough to reach them.
content.location:
Passing

Chocolate Bunny

going downstream, this is the 3rd/last route of the Fish Bowl trio. This is maybe 40 feet from

Big Fish

, in a vague, right-facing corner, above where the old RR bridge used to be. It was dirty, and I broke off some stuff, so be careful.

content.description: Big Fish has enjoyable climbing to powerful moves surmounting the roof and a few more above that. It seemed harder than 10b for me. Alternatively, you can traverse left at the roof then back right on the face if the exposure doesn't bother you (5.9?). Â Rap the route.
content.protection: 9 bolts and 2 draws for the chains.
content.location: This is the middle route and starts at some sloping end layers below the big roof at the top of the route.
